title: Navigating a Fractured Health Care System While Recovering from Substance Abuse

content: As someone with a history of both a substance abuse disorder, as well as other mental health care needs, who has been through his fair share of medical professionals, I get why people don’t want to go to the doctor or hospital when they probably should.
I’ve had an actual licensed therapist tell me people recovering from substance abuse and alcohol “couldn’t be helped” and she’d “find it difficult to treat me.”
Honestly, I wanted to tell her ignorance is learned not inherited and I’d find it difficult to show up to another appointment with her ever again or hold a conversation with her.

Instead, I bit my tongue and just purposely didn’t call or show up at the appointment she brazenly, yet foolishly, set up for the following week. She had literally just finished speaking at length about how bad of a match we were and always would be. How little seeing her would benefit me. Yet, it didn’t stop her from trying to benefit from me financially with an overpriced hour at a time until one of us put an end to the torture. Fat chance, Doc.

content: I’ve had counselors at rehabilitation facilities who made it feel like they openly resented people addicted to drugs and alcohol, and weren’t going to try and even hide it in their daily interactions with us. I wonder if they know there are all sorts of jobs that don’t involve or require a bit of empathy for human life. Tons of ones where the consequences of your actions won’t ever even potentially be a matter of life and death to someone else.
Hippocratic oaths mean more to some than others. Some are looking to collect a check and go home, riding the clock as if they worked at the local Walmart as a part-time greeter.
In fairness, I’ve come across some of the most caring, smart, and knowledgeable individuals at those offices or facilities. The kind that shows up out of care and a sense of duty.

content: In my opinion, the problem with mental health care of any sort is it’s almost as if nobody knows where to start. Because honestly, where do you? Therapy is essentially a never-ending process. You’ll never be “fixed,” because most likely you were never broken, to begin with.

content: Not drinking alcohol and living clean in recovery from addiction or alcoholism are two vastly different things. I’ve done the real work -- the uncomfortable and humbling kind that real recovery entails. The emotional and inside kind most people don’t ever bother to.

Doing so taught me how to be my own best advocate both inside and outside of medical care and treatment facilities. My best advice to anyone having difficulties with their health provider is to be open with them first and foremost. From there, you both have to collectively decide if the issue can be fixed and addressed appropriately, or if it’s in your best interest and maybe even theirs for you to find other help. Whatever you do, keep fighting and keep moving forward. Together, we have a chance.
